content: I've been thinking about this for a bit: having a site that would show E-easy/E-mentored issues. It could potentially be forked off of Servo's starters.servo.org.
Oh, interesting
I vaguely remember something like that existed for a short time in 2018
Is there a strong advantage over just filtering github by tags?
Also, I think one of the bigger challenges as that there just aren't that many E-easy/E-mentor issues, and they tend to be grabbed pretty quickly

I've been doing some work around servo last year and the starters website was actually a nice entry point because its way less frightening that a +5000 issues repo on github where you don't actually know where to look.
Even if you are right at the end, everything is tracked by github with labels so it does not really matter, its just a feeling from newcomers that might prefers the aspect of a starters website.

I think besides E-easy / E-mentor, there are some issues that consist of just adding some tests, I don't know if they are always marked as E-easy. What i found is that usually such issues might not be very straightforward if the needed tests are not regular ui tests, but like miri-opt tests or codegen tests so they could probably have better labelling and pointers to the right documentation to help newcomers handle such issues.

Also, related to E-easy / E-mentor labels when you come to the github repository, nothing directly tells you to look for such labels. Maybe the README could provide a link to github search with those labels? Or maybe a list of labels with a description and a link to github search issues for each of them?
It is mentioned in a few places though generally newcomers may not look there.
I've been thinking about trying to add a page like this to <www.rust-lang.org>, that would also include other rust-lang projects.
I agree with @marmeladema; one of the advantages of a specific starters website is that it feels easier to approach, plus you don't have to manually filter all the time.
So @Nick Cameron had a website like this but I can't remember what it was called :)
one other advantage is in a multi-repo universe
which I personally still would like to see for rustc
but which we have regardless for tools like rustfmt etc
